abstracts.cdata!:
The Treasury Modernization Project for
            Kazakhstan had a satisfactory outcome with likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impact, and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            Borrower.  Lessons learned include the following: Government
            commitment to reform over the entire project duration was a
            critical success factor.  Initially there was resistance
            from some ministries, however, unwavering support enabled
            the Ministry of Finance to achieve the transition. The
            Government's ability to staff the project team with
            competent and dedicated staff was critical during the
            testing and implementation phases.  Functional and
            procedural changes were the major drivers of the reform. The
            technological changes, though the most capital intensive,
            supported the functional reforms. A decision to go for an
            interim computer system to handle core aspects of treasury
            functionality enabled the introduction of change in a
            gradual and a more manageable manner. Close project
            monitoring and advice rendered by the Bank and IMF was
            important.  The requirements for the inclusion of
            appropriately qualified technical staff in the project team
            needs to be recognized in the Bank.  The time needed to
            introduce change at the very basis of budget execution needs
            to be recognized in planning similar projects.  Low
            government pay scales continue to be a crucial impediment to
            attracting and retaining qualified technical staff

5082899.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Treasury Modernization
            Project's overall aim is to support the new Treasury
            Department in establishing a treasury system: a) that
            provides comprehensive, reliable and timely financial
            management information; and b) that helps manage government
            expenditure effectively. To achieve this aim, the project
            sets three specific objectives: a) prepare a detailed
            functional design for the treasury system and develop
            related procedures; b) provide and install the computer
            resources to implement the treasury system; and c) ensure
            that local staff can operate and maintain the system
            effectively. The project consists of the following
            components: a) design of the computerized treasury system;
            b) pilot system computerization; and c) full implementation
            of the computerized system.
